D1.label: Copper Supercycle
D1.description: BHP Group executes on growth strategy; earnings accelerate
D1.plain_english: Structural copper supply deficit emerges as electrification (EVs require 3-4x more copper than ICE vehicles), AI data centre build-out, grid infrastructure upgrades, and renewable energy installations drive demand growth of 3-5% annually. BHP's expanded copper portfolio (Escondida, Olympic Dam, OZ Minerals assets) positions it as one of the top 3 global copper producers. Copper grows from ~25% to 35-40% of group EBITDA by FY2028.
D1.what_to_watch: Next earnings result and forward guidance.
D1.upside: Material re-rating if execution surprises to the upside.
D1.risk_plain: If growth disappoints, this narrative weakens.

D2.label: Iron Ore Cash Machine
D2.description: BHP Group delivers steady-state results; valuation holds
D2.plain_english: Iron ore remains the dominant earnings driver. Pilbara operations produce ~280-290 Mtpa at industry-leading C1 costs of US$15-17/t. Iron ore prices remain supported at US$100-120/t by infrastructure spending, manufacturing demand, and emerging market urbanisation (India). Dividend policy (min 50% payout) plus buybacks generate total returns of 7-9% annually.
D2.risk_plain: If the base case is already priced in, limited upside from here.

D3.label: China Property Drag
D3.description: BHP Group faces headwinds; earnings or multiples compress
D3.plain_english: China's property sector remains in a prolonged downturn (Evergrande, Country Garden defaults). New housing starts have fallen significantly from peak. If China's steel production declines materially, iron ore prices could fall to US$80-90/t, compressing BHP's largest earnings segment by 30-40%. Infrastructure spending provides a partial offset but cannot fully compensate.
D3.what_to_watch: Cost pressures, competitive threats, or macro headwinds.
D3.risk_plain: Material downside if multiple risks crystallise simultaneously.

D4.label: Commodity Cycle Peak
D4.description: A structural shift changes the investment case for BHP Group
D4.plain_english: We are near the top of a commodity supercycle. A global recession or demand shock causes simultaneous declines in iron ore, copper, and met coal prices. BHP's earnings are highly leveraged to commodity prices it does not control. A 2008-style downturn could see a 40-50% earnings decline. The Nickel West impairment (US$2.5B write-down) is a reminder that commodity thesis conviction can prove wrong.
D4.what_to_watch: Industry disruption signals and regulatory changes.
D4.risk_plain: If disruption materialises, prior assumptions become invalid.

big_picture: The market is pricing BHP as a copper transition story layered on top of a cash-generative iron ore base. At A$52.74, the stock trades near 52-week highs (A$52.40), implying confidence in both commodity price resilience and the strategic pivot toward future-facing minerals. The embedded thesis is that iron ore earnings sustain the dividend floor while copper and potash deliver the growth.
